text: Whoosh is a new project which is similar to lucene, but is pure python.
The only one pure-python (not involving even C extension) search solution I know of is Nucular.
It's slow (much slower than PyLucene) and unstable yet.
We moved from PyLucene-based home baked search and indexing to Solr but YMMV.
I recently found pyndexter.
It provides abstract interface to various different backend full-text search engines/indexers.
And it ships with a default pure-python implementation.
These things can be disastrously slow though in Python.
For some applications pure Python is overrated.
Take a look at Xapian.
+1 to the Xapian and Pyndexter answers.
Ferret is actually written in C with Ruby bindings on top.
A pure Ruby search engine would be even slower than a pure Python one.
I would love to see "someone else" write a Cython/Pyrex layer for Python interface to Ferret, but won't do it myself because why bother when there are Python bindings for Xapian.
lupy was a lucene port to pure python.The lupy people suggest that you use PyLucene.
Sorry.
Maybe you can use the Java sources in combination with Jython.

text: After weeks of searching for this, I found a nice Python solution: repoze.catalog.
It's not strictly Python-only because it uses ZODB for storage, but it seems a better dependency to me than something like SOLR.
For non-pure Python, Sphinx Search with Python API work is the fastest.
From the bench marks from multiple blogs .
